repnme.cdata!:
Gabonese - Natural Resources Management
            Development Policy Loan (NRM-DPL) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Natural Resources
            Management Development Policy Loan (NRM-DPL) Project for
            Gabonese were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the NRM-DPL operation is one of
            the few DPLs where Sectoral Investment Lending (SIL) related
            elements were maintained. While in the context of this
            operation, it turned out to be a relevant solution, as
            indicated by the Borrower-, it has generated important
            delays and confusions. It is thus not recommended to
            replicate such 'hybrid' instrument in other
            operations. Governmental reform programs are broad by
            definition. The design phase of a development policy
            operation aims at targeting a set of reforms within the
            overall reform program of the Government in a given sector.
            It is very important that both parties share the same
            understanding of the reforms to be implemented under the
            policy lending as well as the associated prior actions and
            triggers: indicators need to be well-specified, agreed
            up-front with the Borrower, and closely monitored by both
            the Borrower and the Bank during implementation (the policy
            matrix proved to be a useful tool). Any change during
            implementation needs to be jointly discussed and agreed
            upon. When other critical issues emerge during the course of
            the operation, those should not be included as new prior
            actions or triggers (as was the case for the Forest Fund in
            the NRM-DPL operation) but should rather be part of the
            broader policy dialogue between the Bank and the Government.

repnme.cdata!:
Gabon - Natural Resources Management
            Development Policy Loan

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed Natural Resources
            Management Development Policy Loan aims to improve the
            efficiency of natural resources management in Gabon, to
            increase its impact on poverty alleviation, to protect the
            environment, and to reduce the country's dependence on
            declining oil resources. It covers renewable natural
            resources-forests, fisheries, biodiversity and
            environment-as well as the country's mining (mostly
            manganese) and oil sectors. With regard to forest,
            fisheries, biodiversity and environment, the proposed loan
            will support the reform agenda set forth in the May 2004
            letter of Sector Policy which will be implemented through
            the national multi-donor Forest, Fisheries, Biodiversity and
            Environment Sector Program (FESP). The proposed loan will
            also support Gabon's participation in the Extractive
            Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) for oil and mining
            revenues, and it will lay the foundation for broader reforms
            in the mining sector. Policies supported by the proposed
            loan focus on enhancing transparency, accountability and law
            enforcement, on improving the business climate, on ensuring
            equitable sharing of revenues, and on protecting the
            resource-base and natural ecosystems.

repnme.cdata!:
Gabon - Natural Resources Management
            Development Policy Loan Project : resettlement policy
            framework and resettlement process framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The implementation of the Gabon Natural
            Resources Management Development Policy Loan Project will
            impact on the livelihoods and incomes of those living in or
            near protected areas in general and those living in or near
            national parks in particular. Their access to resources will
            most probably be reduced. This combination resettlement
            process framework and resettlement policy framework
            addresses these problems and outlines mitigations. The
            report identifies the people to be affected (PAPs) and
            assesses their specific needs and interests with the aim of
            restoring their livelihoods. While the report does not yet
            determine whether the project must restore villages, along
            with providing land as compensation. To minimize impacts and
            reduce costs, it may be possible to reform the laws to allow
            human activities in the national parks unless villages
            prefer establishing new sites outside the park. PAPs whose
            livelihoods are entirely based on the park will also be
            provided new income opportunities that are non-land-based
            and guarantee the incomes they had in the pre-park
            situation. People whose livelihoods are only partly based on
            the park will be provided the capacities and infrastructure
            to increase the marketing of their products, and the use and
            maintenance of protection measures against the growing
            animal population in the park, such as community hunting
            zones. Those people who have only traditional rights to park
            and protected area resources may be given cash based
            compensation together with some capacity building to invest
            this. Indigenous people, who depend on park or protected
            area resources will be allowed free access as much as
            possible, including a special right of the Baka people to
            hunt elephants under park supervision. The Baka will also be
            offered social services for free in exchange for a ban on
            commercial hunting on protected species or large scale hunting.

repnme.cdata!:
Gabon - Natural Resources Management
            Development Policy Loan Project : environmental and social assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental and social assessment
            for the Gabon Natural Resources Management Development
            Policy Loan Project, which improves transparency and law
            enforcement for natural resource management, anticipates
            likely environmental impacts and discusses measures to
            mitigate them. The most significant potentially negative
            environmental impacts include overexploitation of non-wood
            forest products by installing badly controlled channels;
            increased solid waste and liquid effluents leading to
            increased river and aquifer pollution from industrial
            chemicals; uncontrolled forestry logging triggering losses
            of income leading to increased poaching, urban migration,
            and social conflicts; reduced biodiversity in freshwater
            ecosystems, possibly causing extinction of some species;
            uncontrolled exploitation of some aquatic species; and
            development of tourist activities incompatible with
            biodiversity conservation. Key social issues include crop
            destruction caused by wild animals; loss of access to land
            and traditional fishing grounds; loss of income
            opportunities; and uncertainty concerning the legal status
            of immigrants working in the sector. Measures to reduce
            these risks are as follows: Reinforce CENAP (the national
            environmental protection agency) to strengthen its role in
            controlling and analyzing pollution, especially regarding
            standards and laboratory protocols; monitor forest permits
            and reinforce the regulatory and legal framework; and
            provide training in protected areas management, solid waste
            and liquid effluent management, regulatory enforcement, and
            forest management.

repnme.cdata!:
Gabon - Natural Resources Management
            Development Policy Loan Project : indigenous peoples
            development plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This objective of the indigenous peoples
            development plan for the Natural Resources Management and
            National Parks and Biodiversity Conservation Project is to
            ensure that the PFSE and the GEF projects respect the
            dignity, rights, and culture of the indigenous people in
            Gabon and provides them equal and culturally appropriate
            benefits. This report discusses strategies for achieving
            this aim. The indigenous people of Gabon are identified as
            the Babongo, Bakoya, Baka, Barimba, Bagama, Bakouyi, and
            Akoa - the pygmies. The risks resulting from this project
            which threaten to impact thee people include: loss of
            control over traditional land, becoming even more
            marginalized in society; disintegration of the decentralized
            system of administration, less assistance received from
            government services, fewer capacities to defend their legal
            rights, dependency on other ethnic groups, loss of cultural
            and social identity. To offset these potential risks, the
            plan will establish equal legal opportunities, technical
            opportunities, financial opportunities, organizational
            opportunities, and cultural opportunities. Among the
            activities planned are putting in place capacity and
            structure, providing ID cards, recognizing the settlements
            as villages equal to other settlements, establishing
            community forests, recognizing and protecting the land use
            areas of indigenous people, announcing a national policy on
            illegal immigrants, enabling the indigenous to actively
            participate in natural resource management, improving
            intercultural communication, improving research to provide
            baseline information, ensuring indigenous people receive a
            fair share of the redistribution of forest revenue,
            facilitating forest-related decision-making,   and
            establishing a participatory monitoring and evaluation system.
